item.title: Covid: Most rules set to end in England, says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson says the success of the vaccine means England can begin to look beyond restrictions.

item.title: Roberts Buncis: Boy, 15, convicted of knife murder of friend
item.description: Roberts Buncis was stabbed more than 70 times in the attack just two days before his 13th birthday.

item.title: Boris Johnson admits it's ludicrous he's PM, says Cummings
item.description: The former aide launches another attack on the PM, but also defends his decision to work for him.

item.title: Captain Sir Tom laid to rest in hometown of Keighley
item.description: The NHS fundraiser and WW2 veteran died aged 100 in February after testing positive for Covid-19.

item.title: Covid-19: England lockdown easing plans, and Kate self-isolates
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Monday evening.

item.title: Afghanistan: Soldiers flee to Tajikistan after Taliban clashes
item.description: More than 1,000 soldiers retreat to Tajikistan as fighting with the militants intensifies.

item.title: Duchess of Cambridge forced to self-isolate due to Covid contact
item.description: Kensington Palace says the Duchess of Cambridge is not experiencing any coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Ever Given: Egypt agrees deal to release ship that blocked Suez Canal
item.description: Egypt agrees a compensation deal with the impounded Ever Given's owners and insurers.

item.title: Van sales soar amid home delivery boom
item.description: While demand for vans rises, new car sales remain sluggish as computer chip shortages limit supplies.

item.title: Jewish man abused twice in an hour on London transport network
item.description: The abusers were willing to target the man even though they knew they were on CCTV, his brother says.

item.title: Soul Cap: Afro swimming cap Olympic rejection could be reconsidered after backlash
item.description: The governing body had told Soul Cap their hats don't follow "the natural form of the head".

item.title: Boris Johnson: 'If we can't reopen in next few weeks, when will we?'
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson speaks about the final step of England's roadmap out of lockdown.

item.title: My 'lovely' calves: Irish 10-year-old swaps cash prize for herd
item.description: Irish 10-year-old William Woods has been cow-unting his blessings after buying calves with the winnings from a prize draw.

item.title: NHS Covid thanksgiving service: 'They did what they could to save my life'
item.description: A doctor, a patient and a volunteer reflect on Covid-19, as a thanksgiving service is held at St Paul's.

item.title: After Lod violence, Israeli city's residents fear for the future
item.description: Both Jewish and Arab Israelis feel unprotected after intercommunal violence in the Israeli city.

item.title: Trafalgar Square Fourth Plinth: Winning design a 'litmus test' for society
item.description: The central London landmark has been home to a rolling commission of artworks since 1998.

item.title: Plaque in Micheldever marks first UK car journey
item.description: A plaque commemorates the first recorded UK car journey by Evelyn Ellis in Hampshire in1895.

item.title: Where is the anti-lockdown movement headed?
item.description: What is set to become of the growing anti-lockdown movement once Covid restrictions are lifted?

item.title: Olympic hopeful spent lockdown training 'in a makeshift pool'
item.description: Record-breaking 17-year-old Evie Davis from Bromley has set her sights on swimming at the Olympics in Paris.

item.title: Brexit: Exporting my fish to China is easier than to France
item.description: A Scottish fisherman says post-Brexit rules means three hours worth of paperwork for each EU order.

item.title: Escaping a serial killer - and moving on
item.description: Kara Chamberlain was kidnapped when she was 15. Now she talks about her trauma on social media.

item.title: UFOs: 'These objects show physics we don't understand'
item.description: An astronautical engineering expert on the unanswered questions in the US government's UFO report.

item.title: Israeli videographer goes viral with sheep drone shots
item.description: Lior Patel's drone footage of sheep has been viewed more than 100,000 times on Facebook.

item.title: Benefits and disability: 'I'll never cohabit again, to protect myself'
item.description: Some disabled people have been left uncomfortably reliant on partners after benefits were removed.

item.title: Is the use of jetpacks finally about to take off?
item.description: Members of the public can now pay to fly through the air like a superhero.

item.title: Letter from Africa: Lamenting the Algeria-Morocco border closure
item.description: The Morocco-Algeria border has been closed for decades, despite close ties between the people.

item.title: Protests, pet thefts and sex crimes: MPs want changes to the policing bill
item.description: The controversial Policing, Crime, Sentencing and Courts bill is back in the Commons on Monday.

item.title: Jeff Bezos steps down as Amazon boss
item.description: As Bezos leaves his role as CEO, those who have worked with him ponder the lessons learned.

item.title: Pandemic investing: 'Using my part-time pay to invest in stocks'
item.description: Interest in investing and trading grew during the Covid pandemic, but experts warn of the risks.

item.title: Archaeologists dig in over planning reforms row
item.description: Experts warn history and heritage could be lost if they are excluded from the government's new plans.

item.title: 'The opportunity to bring happiness for our fans, our nation, is very special'
item.description: England have a "very special opportunity" to make the country happy when they face Denmark in their Euro 2020 semi-final, says Gareth Southgate.

item.title: Anderson takes 1,000th first-class wicket
item.description: England's James Anderson takes 7-19 - including his 1,000th first-class wicket - to help Lancashire reduce skittle Kent inside a session for just 74.

item.title: On the verge of greatness - can Cavendish break Tour stage win record?
item.description: After an eventful week at the Tour de France, it's all falling Mark Cavendish's way, so what does he have to do to break Eddy Merckx's record?

item.title: NHL goaltender Kivlenieks dies after party fall
item.description: Columbus Blue Jackets goaltender Matiss Kivlenieks dies after sustaining a head injury in a fall at a house party.

item.title: World number one Barty into first Wimbledon quarter-finals
item.description: World number one Ashleigh Barty reaches the Wimbledon quarter-finals for the first time with a 7-5 6-3 victory over Barbora Krejcikova.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but rules are changing in England.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: The PM says every adult should have had the chance to be doubled jabbed by mid-September.

item.title: Covid: Will free school meals continue over summer holidays?
item.description: A year on from Marcus Rashford's successful campaign, what is the current situation?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: The prime minister is due to announce the next steps for social distancing rules in England.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: The government is considering allowing double vaccinated adults to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: 'Coercion and rape': Investigating my yoga school
item.description: Ishleen Kaur was passionate about yoga movement Sivananda, until she found allegations of sexual abuse.

item.title: British Jews' fear and defiance amid record monthly anti-Semitism reports
item.description: Some 460 anti-Semitic incidents were reported to the Community Security Trust from 8 May to 7 June.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.
